metadata.title: LEARNING TO MAKE ANALOGIES BY CONTRASTING ABSTRACT RELATIONAL STRUCTURE
metadata.author: Felix Hill, Adam Santoro, David G. T. Barrett, Ari Morcos & Tim Lillicrap Deepmind, London {felixhill,adamsantoro,barrettdavid,arimorcos,countzero}@google.com
metadata.abstract: Analogical reasoning has been a principal focus of various waves of AI research. Analogy is particularly challenging for machines because it requires relational structures to be represented such that they can be flexibly applied across diverse domains of experience. Here, we study how analogical reasoning can be induced in neural networks that learn to perceive and reason about raw visual data. We find that the critical factor for inducing such a capacity is not an elaborate architecture, but rather, careful attention to the choice of data and the manner in which it is presented to the model. The most robust capacity for analogical reasoning is induced when networks learn analogies by contrasting abstract relational structures in their input domains, a training method that uses only the input data to force models to learn about important abstract features. Using this technique we demonstrate capacities for complex, visual and symbolic analogy making and generalisation in even the simplest neural network architectures.

highlights: The ability to make analogies – that is, to flexibly map familiar relations from one domain of experience to another – is a fundamental ingredient of human intelligence and creativity (Gentner, 1983; Hofstadter, 1996; Hummel & Holyoak, 1997; Lovett & Forbus, 2017)

Our model consisted of a simple perceptual front-end – a convolutional neural network (CNN) – which provided input for a recurrent neural network (RNN) by producing embeddings for each image panel independently

In the case of interpolation, we found that a model trained with random candidates performs very poorly on the more challenging contrasting test questions (Fig 4c 45% vs 93% for Learning Analogies By Contrasting), which suggests that models trained in the normal regime overfit to a strategy that bears no resemblance to human-like analogical reasoning
CONCLUSION. These results demonstrate that Learning Analogies By Contrasting increases the ability of models to generalize beyond the distribution of their training data

Our experiments show that simple neural networks can learn to make analogies with visual and symbolic inputs, but this is critically contingent on the way in which they are trained; during training, the correct answers should be contrasted with alternative incorrect answers that are plausible at the level of relations rather than simple perceptual attributes
We find that models that are trained by Learning Analogies By Contrasting to reason better by analogy are, perhaps surprisingly, better able to extrapolate to a wider range of input values
key_statements: The ability to make analogies – that is, to flexibly map familiar relations from one domain of experience to another – is a fundamental ingredient of human intelligence and creativity (Gentner, 1983; Hofstadter, 1996; Hummel & Holyoak, 1997; Lovett & Forbus, 2017)
In this work we demonstrate that well-known neural network architectures can learn to make analogies with remarkable generality and flexibility

We find that Learning Analogies By Contrasting greatly enhances the ability of our networks to resolve analogies in a generalisable way by encouraging them to compare inputs at the more abstract level of relations rather than the less abstract level of attributes

Our model consisted of a simple perceptual front-end – a convolutional neural network (CNN) – which provided input for a recurrent neural network (RNN) by producing embeddings for each image panel independently
We found that the network can learn to make sense of the unfamiliar target domains in the test questions, again this capacity is boosted by Learning Analogies By Contrasting (Fig 4b)

In the case of interpolation, we found that a model trained with random candidates performs very poorly on the more challenging contrasting test questions (Fig 4c 45% vs 93% for Learning Analogies By Contrasting), which suggests that models trained in the normal regime overfit to a strategy that bears no resemblance to human-like analogical reasoning
CONCLUSION. These results demonstrate that Learning Analogies By Contrasting increases the ability of models to generalize beyond the distribution of their training data

CONCLUSION. These results demonstrate that Learning Analogies By Contrasting increases the ability of models to generalize beyond the distribution of their training data. This effect is observed for the prototypical analogical processes involving novel domain mappings and unfamiliar target domains (Experiments 1 & 2)
To understand the mechanisms that support this generalisation we analysed neural activity in models trained with Learning Analogies By Contrasting compared to models that were not
For a model trained via greater distinctions between different abstract relations in Learning Analogies By Contrasting, we found that these activi- the representation space of models

To verify our findings in this setting, we implemented a symbolic analogy task based on feature-based stimuli. This more controlled domain allows to show that the construction of appropriate incorrect answer candidates can be learned in a proposal model that is trained jointly with a model that learns to contrast the candidates, widening the potential applications of Learning Analogies By Contrasting to task settings where we lack a clear understanding of the underlying abstract relational structure (Sec 5.3)

If instead we were to generate random vectors as candidates, the models could learn and embed all possible f ∈ F into their weights, and choose the correct answer by process of elimination; any candidate that does not satisfy f (Vt) for any f is necessarily an incorrect candidate. This method does not require any analogical reasoning, since the model can outright ignore the relation instantiated in the source set, which is precisely a type of back-door solution characteristic of neural network approaches

Our experiments show that simple neural networks can learn to make analogies with visual and symbolic inputs, but this is critically contingent on the way in which they are trained; during training, the correct answers should be contrasted with alternative incorrect answers that are plausible at the level of relations rather than simple perceptual attributes
This is consistent with the Structure Mapping Theory of human analogy-making, which highlights the importance of inter-domain comparison at the level of abstract relational structures
We find that models that are trained by Learning Analogies By Contrasting to reason better by analogy are, perhaps surprisingly, better able to extrapolate to a wider range of input values
Our results show that neural networks are not fundamentally limited in this respect
summary: The ability to make analogies – that is, to flexibly map familiar relations from one domain of experience to another – is a fundamental ingredient of human intelligence and creativity (Gentner, 1983; Hofstadter, 1996; Hummel & Holyoak, 1997; Lovett & Forbus, 2017).
This ability, is critically dependent on a method of training we call learning analogies by contrasting abstract relational structure (LABC).

Learning Analogies By Contrasting (LABC) In the default setting of our data generator – the normal training regime – for a question involving source domain ds, target domain dt and relation r, the candidate answers can contain any values chosen at random from dt (Fig. 2).

We can make this less likely by instead training the model to contrast abstract relational structure – the LABC regime – by ensuring that incorrect answers are both perceptually and semantically plausible (Fig. 2).
To make sense of the test questions, a model must learn to represent the relations in the dataset in a sufficiently general way that this knowledge can be applied to completely novel domains.

Accuracy in the LABC condition on the most focused test questions is lower than in the Experiment 1 (∼ 80%, depending on the held-out domain), but well above the model trained with random answer candidates (∼ 60%).

In the case of interpolation, we found that a model trained with random candidates performs very poorly on the more challenging contrasting test questions (Fig 4c 45% vs 93% for LABC), which suggests that models trained in the normal regime overfit to a strategy that bears no resemblance to human-like analogical reasoning.

This more controlled domain allows to show that the construction of appropriate incorrect answer candidates can be learned in a proposal model that is trained jointly with a model that learns to contrast the candidates, widening the potential applications of LABC to task settings where we lack a clear understanding of the underlying abstract relational structure (Sec 5.3).

As in the visual analogy tasks, to resolve such a question the model must detect an abstract relationship in the input domain ds, that explains the connection between the source stimuli Vs and the answer vector a[Vs,ds,f].

This method does not require any analogical reasoning, since the model can outright ignore the relation instantiated in the source set, which is precisely a type of back-door solution characteristic of neural network approaches.

Our experiments show that simple neural networks can learn to make analogies with visual and symbolic inputs, but this is critically contingent on the way in which they are trained; during training, the correct answers should be contrasted with alternative incorrect answers that are plausible at the level of relations rather than simple perceptual attributes.
headline: We study how analogical reasoning can be induced in neural networks that learn to perceive and reason about raw visual data
